text:
This is for a 2015 bottle I just purchased. Poured and looked like a cider. Almost smelled like a cider, a funky cider. Taste though..............tasted sweet with a not-so-subtle aftertaste of urine. I imagine this is what diabetic urine tasted like before the invention of insulin. Thats right, this cider tastes like sweetened piss. Do yourself a favor and, instead of buying this saccharine pee, read this article about all the things doctors in the 1800s learned about tasting their patients urine. Its a much less terrible way to spend your free time.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverythi

Draught @ Mig & Ølsnedkeren, Aarhus, 2012 vintage. Pours light golden, no head, some light bubbles. Aroma of tart apples, yeast, barnyard, apple core. Flavor is light tart, rich apples, yeast, barnearm, wood, apple core. Medium body, average to lively carboantion, dry and light tart fruity finish. 280417

Tap at Beerttoria. Lovely smell, reminiscent of childhood cider lollies some how. Loads of apple, the intensity of which swirls around. Taste is great too, rich fruitiness, apples of course. Cant rate ciders it seems... very nice though. Tiny bit of sweetness. But just so much apple.

Pours a medium light golden hue with a half finger of fizzy foam. Nose is soft apple flesh, hint of caramel sweetness, funky old wood and a touch of spice and acid. Palate has a lush round soft caramelized apple note that holds firm to balance some austere funky barnyard nuances with tannic apple skin hints and a lingering woodsy spice.

Sampled on draft at Monks Cafe this beer poured a dark golden color with a small foamy white head that left no lacing. The aroma was musty and bretty with a bit of apple flesh. The flavor was apple flesh, mustiness, a bit tart and earthy. Long musty apple flesh finish. Medium body. Ok.

(Kiev 2016). 375 ml. bottle. 2012 Vintage. Shared by 4. Loud pop upon opening. Pours an insanely lively sparkling golden, more lively than Champagne, huge white head that instantly fizzes way, lemon golden, crazily lively brew. Nose is very raw barnyard & funk, brett, fermenting apples, mineral apples, raw apple skin funk, brett, wowza didnt see this much funk coming from a cider. Taste is raw barnyard funk, insanely lively beer, apple skins, fermenting apples, rotting lemon, brett, hay, barnyard. So much carbonation & so much funk. Very unusual for me at first & quite challenging. Almost admired it more than I liked but it grew on me and I started appreciating a bit. Dry beyond the massive carbonation.

On tap at White Oak Tavern in Ellicott City. Crystal clear light amber color. Thin head. Aroma of apples and funky barnyard smells. Taste is tart and full of apples. Nice carbonation. This was a very pleasant surprise. Very easy to drink.

375 ml. Vintage 2014. Petite mousse pétillante qui sefface rapidement sur un corps doré finement embrouillé. Au nez, pommes rustiques et cuir, fleurs poivrées et parfum animal. Sur les papilles, des levures sauvages accrochées sur les pelures de pommes qui me conduisent à une finale musquée. Belle présentation en bouche. Huileuse et pétillante. Un art maîtrisé.

Now heres a higher priced cider that might be worth the trouble. A little dusty on the nose, which isnt something I like, but also some light funk, which I do. Apples of course, and a little floral note in the nose. Flavor is a touch tart and lively, as is the carbonation.

Pictured bottle, 2014 vintage from Louisville Beer Store; shared with my Boo. Aroma: Light bittersweet juice with some farmhouse notes (feet and funky cheese) taking a more prominent role; some lighter wildflower notes. Appearance: Copperish gold body with lively carbonation holding up a patchy white head. Flavor: Funky apple peel up front and throughout; bittersweet juice takes a peek towards the finish, which is dry and funky. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, lively carbonation, long finish. Overall: Delicious, funky farmhouse cider that has a definite moreish quality. A bit of a revelation with the last of my Blue Stilton.

Vintage 2014 Bottle from the Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma is musty, with lots of hints of fermented cow corn and barnyard funk present. Light metallic, and some stale urine is also present. Transparent yellow body with a fizzy, white, bubbly, quickly dissipating head. Starts with a pleasant apple sweetness, but not too sweet. Becomes a little more tart in the middle with some drying and dusty yeast character. Bright and bubbly with some cereal like sweetness to finish. This is pretty damn tasty. The aroma is kind of too urine-like for me, but thankfully it drinks much much better.

750ml bottle. Clear bright golden color with a lasting white head. Really nice appearance. Aroma has crisp apple, barnyard, bread, and floral notes. The flavor is really nice. Sweet yet not overly so, slightly acidic, very fresh. The palate is crisp and effervescent with a nice mild astringency. Medium body. A really nice cider! One of the best of the few Ive ticked.
Bottle at Villain & Saint. Nice golden body with no head at all. Nose is sweet with apples and a bit funky. Taste is apples for sure, quite alcy, with sweet and some spicier notes in the finish.

Fantastic aroma that starts spice and perfume then quickly changes to funk, must, apples, bit of leather. Appearance has a nice medium amber with lots of bubble trails. Flavor is a weird blend of tasty cider and band aids. Body is great and made better by the strong carbonation. Great drinking. Would very much like to try it on draft.

On tap at Novare Res. Pours a moderately hazy golden with a thin foam on top that leaves foamy lacing. Nose is of barnyard-y brett, leathery. Taste is lightly sweet and lightly funky and spicy too. Body is light to medium and carbonation high. Really nice!

750 ml. bottle. It pours very clear yellow with a fizzy, disappearing white head. The aroma jumps out as rather funky, with a touch of sulfur, yeast, white grape, hay and apples. It kind of reminds me of a brett beer by the smell of it due to my relative ignorance of ciders. The flavor is more apple forward, but still has some toasty hay-like funk and bready yeast. Theres definitely a distinct "farmhouse" character here that balances the sweetness from the apples perfectly. The mouthfeel is light, but the sweet apples make it feel bigger. Ok, now I think Ill be getting into ciders a bit more. Delicious.
2013 bottle. Faint aroma of sour funk, apples and Chardonnay. Champagne effervescence. Very dry, and surprisingly unflavorful. Glad the funk doesnt build. Smooth, refreshing, and easy to drink.

Bottle 750ml. [2013]
Pours golden with low off-white head. Aroma is of apples, juice, sugar, some sulphur. Taste is of apples, sugar, acidity, something off. Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Overall: Good, but nothing really outstanding. Still a nice drink.

Bottle (750 ml). 2013 vintage. Thanks to kcherney for this one! Split with the Québec & Trois-Rivières crew.

Appearance: Clear golden-orange with a small bubbly white head, low retention and little lacing. 

Aroma: Quite a bit of sulfur along apples, light brettanomyces and mineral notes.

Taste: Sulfur notes again, but way less than in the aroma. Light brettanomyces and tartness. Aplles, light caramel, strong mineral presence and dusty notes.

Palate: Light to medium body. Moderate to medium carbonation. Mineral finish. 

Overall: Pretty good cider, but a tad too much sulfur in the aroma and not nearly as good as the "organic" version I tried a few months ago. Still, its tasty and easy drinking stuff.

pours almost clear bright gold with a small bubbly white cap. SO2-plenty; floral honey, brown sugar, hint of sweetness - honey; bretts and other bugs. average carbonation, light body, semi-sweet and very chalky finish. o-k.

Bottle,shared. Clear deep gold pour with white head. Aroma is really funky, mineral notes, tons of wet grass, sulphur. Taste is very mineral, apple juice with quite a bit of funk. Palate is light bodied with light carbonation.
its so delicious. complex, dry, funky. definitely different than what you might think of when you think "cider" (but this is what real cider can taste like--not sugary apple water). world-class.

Tap at Bull and Bush. Clear golden with no head. Woody funky nose like the hostel I stayed at in Scotland, with an unfortunate methane-like back end. Full flavor with a wee touch of that methane flavor on the beginning, with a crisp earthy and dusty Apple flavor in the middle, and a slight boozy kick on the end. Very different and Im not sure I like it.
bottle, not sweet at all, great nuances apple flavors, lightly carbed, very nice and tasted very rustic

2012 Vintage. 375mL bottle at Brouwers Cafe, pours a clear blonde with a large white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is wonderful, with loads of brett and farmhouse character. Flavour is funky as hell, with loads of farmhouse funk, yeast, and champagne. Wonderful stuff. A word class cider.
Bottle - Farmhouse, manure and apple. Clear gold with a bubbly white head. Apple, vanilla and a nice sweetness. Effervescent with a reasonably dry finish. Really nice.

Bottle direct from the cidery in Aug 2014 but it was 2013 vintage. Golden and quite fizzing in the glass. Sweet eating apples on the nose, quite sweet with a hint of coriander. Quite fizzy on the mouth - a nice drop!
2011 bottle. Golden, really very lively. Funky farmyard aroma. Fruity, mature apples, dust, farmyard. Lightish body. A pleasant surprise- refreshing, yet quite complex and balanced.

Draft at Dutchs in late June/early July this year. Pours a hazy golden with a hint of orange and no head. The aroma and flavor have sweet apples and pears, a nice tartness grows, some musty character shows, more interesting than most ciders.
Bottle direct from the cidery. Pours golden with a thin white head. Quite well sparkling giving a full mouthfeel. Sweet apple flavour with sherbet and a mild herbal note. Crisp and fresh.

August 29, 2014. Bottle, 2012 vintage. 
Gusher, leaving 3/4 left in the bottle. 
Pours clear golden with a quickly dissipating frothy white head, Aroma is tart apples, oak, vanilla, barnyard. Taste is light sweet fruity, medium tart apples with a barnyard finish. Medium dry bodied, fizzy carbonation.
Draft at Green Lady. REally phenominal normandie cidre, some dustiness, tannic skins, some decent acidity, oxidized but crisp and tart.

Champagne bottle at YNWA Beershop. No head. Clear yellow golden body. Mild dusty aplle plastic aroma. High carbonated fresh apples with notes of lemon and lime. A bit agressive and acidic. Long finish.

I expected more from this. In a lot of ways it was like a champagne - really fizzy and somewhat dry, but there was a bit of sweetness to it. I kept trying to place one of the main flavors and the closest I could come up with was a champagne like flavor.

hazy, cloudy, sparkling, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, fizzy, golden,

Bottled. Pours clear and yellow with a tiny white head. Aroma of apples, funk and wood. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry andtart. Medium bodied, watery to oily texture and average carb. A.very nice and crisp Cider.

Light gold, clear, fine and lasting bubbles. 
Medium body and flavor density, spritzy, low alcohol heat, avg length. 
Very sweet, balancing acidity, slightly fermented apple taste. 
Tasty but a bit too sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012, 375 ml into a tulip. Crystal clear light amber with tons of rising carbonation. Nose is blue cheese. Musky, funky, and a little smoked meats. Light apples but the nose rivals some lambic in the level of musk. Taste is musk, hay, and and some meat. Savory transforms to sweet aged apples with a lingering oaky/oxidation earthiness. Dry and bubbly. Takes a bit to get used to the musk but once you do its actually quite good and very unique.

Opens with a gigantic pop. Pours a hazy straw gold with a big bubbled white head champagne-like cap that settles quickly to nothing, leaving an actively carbed body behind. Nose involves tart apple skin, a distinctive farm quality with deep complexity, maybe a hint of rubber, quite a challenging nose. Somewhat sweet, quite tart. Light, very active, refreshing yet soft, with a lengthy farmy yeast and bone-dry finish. Excellent cider, so much to take in, very enjoyable.

Draft to taster at Dutchs. Looks solid; a Oslo transparent lighter gold with ample off-white head that dissipates entirely fairly quickly. Smells of tart apples. A bit of sweetness, but not to the point that Id call it a sweet cider. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Could definitely be dryer. A decent cider, but forgettable.
Bottle @ Pizzeria Paradise, Georgetown, Washington DC. Hazy yellow body with a small white head. Yeast, tart, vinegar, apples, fruit, dry, acetic, fizzy carbonation. Decent.

On tap at Dutchs. Pours with a bigger head, that soon fades to minimal. My pour is one of the first from the keg. Half hazy golden color, with chunky stringy particles visible in the body -- not sure if thats pieces of apple or yeast, but it doesnt bother me either way. Light to medium body. Super smooth and crisp lighter carbonation. Very lightly slick finish, minimal stickiness. Intensely drinkable and refreshing, even on the full stomach I have right now. Fantastic golden apple aroma, pretty clean. Moderate sweet taste. Awesome surprisingly poundable refreshing easy-drinking cidre.

750ml bottle, at 5% ABV, but Im pretty certain it is this cider. Pours a hazy pale gold, with fine trailing bubbles. Smoky notes, leather and dusty apple skin make up the aroma. A little lemon up front is soon overcome by charry wood and tart apple. Smoke and cured meats give it a nicely savoury finish. A high quality dry Normandy cider.

Bottle. Cloudy orange body with loads of visible bubbles. Nose is wood, sawdust, apple cores, yellow apple peel, hints of floral honey tones. Taste is apple cores, yellow apple peel, sawdust, oak and hints of straw and dry leaves. Smooth, bubbly mouthfeel, semi-dry finish. Very nice cider in the Normandie tradition.

Pours a light golden with some very bubbly, effervescent white head. Nose is really funky and musty. Flavor is much the same, with some apple tartness, some yeasty notes. Why cant all cider be this complex and intersting?
2011 bottle. Slightly hazy golden pour with a thin white head. Aroma of apple wine. Flavor is slightly dry with champagne-like carbonation. Not bad but not my favorite.

375 mL bottle from Willow Park Wines & Spirits in Calgary, served in a stem glass. Pours hazy orange-golden with a medium, rocky white head that fades immediately to leave a rim of bubbles. The nose has notes of apples and earth along with subtle lavender, rose and funk. The flavour is slightly sweet up front with apples, flowers and funk, but it dries out towards the end. The finish is long and dry with floral notes and grass. On the palate it is light in body with a dryish texture and Champagne-style carbonation. Overall, a great apple cider. Nicely floral and dry, it is quite complex and satisfying. 2014-03-10

Very unique and tasty cidre with a hazy yellowish pour as well as a thin veil of white bubbly head. The nose is extremely floral and perfumey with notes of rose petals, lavender and grass clippings. Mildly sweet and a bit bubbly on the palate with a nice crisp finish. Not as flowery as the nose.

Golden pour with a slight haze (if you dont unsettle the sediment). Vibrant white head that dissipates rapidly to a champagne effervescence. Nose of cork, leather, funk, fresh fruit. Bright on the palate with strong notes of sour green apple, peach, grass and earth funk - the sourness is quick though leaving a slightly sweet green apple flavour and aroma. This is a really nice treat. Not a daily driver...

Great cider . I am not big expert but this is very good . Pale golden color , champagne head. Tart apple aroma . Light sweetness and light sourness in taste with oaks notes . Good balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Aggressive carbonation, basic cider aroma. Strength of this is just that its so balanced. Neither sweet or tart stands out. Refined. High end, perhaps occasionally worth the price, but not so sure I need to have it again.

Draft sampled at Pizzeria Paradiso Dupont. Pours clear golden with no head. Aroma of apples, toffee, some barnyard and vegetables. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
On draft at Pizzeria Paradiso. Pours a clear gold. Tart and funky apple nose. Some caramel notes.

2011 vintage. Explodes out of the bottle - get out your mop. Otherwise, pours clear and gold with a gigantic white head that dissipates immediately. Aroma is funky sharp barnyard, seltzer water, and faint lemony vinegar. Taste is sweet apples fading to a oaky brettanomyces medicinal-like finish.

750 ml bottle. Vintage 2011. 7/29/13. Highly pressurized. Mind the cork and cage. Pours a light straw color with incredibly active, rolling carbonation; a thick whitehead that was very fast to fade. Aroma is apple, vinegar, farmyard, funk, grass, some wood, some spice. Taste is dry, vinous, fruity, fresh, refreshing; apple, pear, white wine vinegar, wood (oak), grass; finish is subtle bitterness of apple peel and white grape skins. Taste is reminiscent of breathing in a spring afternoon atop a grassy hill. Light-medium bodied. Mouth feel is crisp and thin. Carbonation is very high and lively. No lacing. This is really something. Highly enjoyable.

Bottle from Stearns. Golden pour with a huge white head and tons of fizz. Whew, this is funky. Smoke, blue cheese, apple, and yeast. A bit of peach, barnyard, and herbs. The flavor is pretty funky as well. Lots of barnyard, some leather, and earth. Herbs, apple, blue cheese, and peach. Light sweetness, but a very drying, almost tannic finish.
Holy cow, one of the craziest beers I tasted today, thanks to WomenCantSail, very unique taste, cow patty, unpasteurized, insane taste.

375ml (2011 vintage - 12124) - Im so glad I read Phaleslus rating before opening this bottle; as soon as the wire is unscrewed, the cork just took off (into my cupped hand). Pours like champagne with vigorous bubblage. Pale straw color with super quickly diminishing white head. Nose is cork and apples. Flavor adds duh funk indeed. sweet and sour. I would prefer the calvados from this "producteur". A very fizzy cider. Refreshing after spending three hours moving rock. Long apple aftertaste. Gets better as the carbonation settles down.

750 mL bottle, vintage 2011. Clouded golden pour, very fizzy. Strongly dry tart funky apple aroma, a little barn-y. Flavor at first is dry tart apple and herb, some bretty funk. Smoky wood at times like bacon. More unidentifiable subtle complexities. Juicy, but with a tongue-drying finish. Certainly a good one.

375mL bottle, 2010 vintage. Poured cleared, bright golden with a short-lived, fizzy white head. The aroma picked up champagne-like vinous notes paired with apple essence.. meatier apples as it warmed up.. seemed like it was going to be on the tart/sour side. The flavor found tart apple skins and white vinous notes throughout.. more sour and almost gueuze-lite-ish on the finish.. tasty stuff. Very dry on the palate with prickly carbonation.. tart, refreshing, and engaging.. really good stuff!

375 ml bottle. Cork popped right after cage removed - a mess. Pours gold with huge head of big bubbles that dissipate right away. Aromas of manure and over ripe apples. Flavour of applesauce , , hay, and light citrus. Nice enough but the aroma sneaks in to ruin the taste.

While this may not be the Reserve aged in Calvados, it IS readily available and relatively affordable. Crisp, tart, and refreshing with an even more pronounced Brett character, but without the musty notes. 

Side note: I have enjoyed this straight up, and blended with small amounts of Calvados ( bring it up to 7.5% ABV like the Reserev), and every combination works very well

Bottle at Pdx 2013 cider summit - pours a cloudy golden color. Interesting aroma of grass and hay. Taste of sweet apple, slightly boozy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml bottle from madeincalvados.com. 2011 vintage. Dark golden color with thin head. Carbonation is very high but still is nice. Taste is very balanced but tends to be sweet. Aroma is very balanced. Nice!

750 ml bottle from Randalls. 2010 vintage. The cork blasts off when the cage is loosened, with a champagne-like initial gush that settles quickly. Pours a hazy dull gold with an initially fizzy, lively head that fizzes out quickly and settles with no head. Some floaters settle at the bottom of the glass. Very earthy, oaky aroma, with barnyard funk and apples. The flavor follows suit; the apples are backed by lots of earthy funk, oak, and leather. Light-medium bodied, with a funky mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. More complex than a typical cider; my wife didnt like it as much because she likes a more straightforward tart apple character, but I liked this traditional take on the style.

Refrigerated green 375 mL 2011 bottle obtained through trade with JStax corked and caged poured into a white wine glass.  Pours clear pale golden with fluffy carbonation which dies down.  Aroma is simple dry apple, extreme carbonation (the cork went airborne and landed 15 feet away.  Taste is dry apple, oak, and a hint of skunk (quite using green bottles).  If you like dry ciders this is good.

2011 bottle. Poured into a tulip. Pours hay with good carbonation. Aroma is funky apple cider. Taste is very funky and tart, a bit of wet dog, horse blanket. Lots of carbonation on the tongue. Definitely a cider for fans of funky and sour beers.

First time rating a cider on here.  Thought Id make it a good one.  750ml bottle (2011 vintage) in a flute.  Pours the color of apple juice with a quickly dissipating, white head.  Aroma of apple juice with light spices and some herbal notes.  Flavor the same with a little alcohol.  Texture like champagne.  A good cider.

Sampled at the 2013 Chicago Cider Summit. Pours a clear pale gold with a bubbly white head that starts at the edges and dissipates completely, visible carbonation. Aroma has musty apple with a combination of sweet and tart notes. Flavor is quite musty with more tart apples and a bit of funkiness in the finish.

From bottle. This thing is crazy carbonated...barely unwound the metal wire when the cork flew off and bottle started overflowing. Looks between straw and gold. Thick head that is very volatile and quickly reduces to a thin film. Smells just like a fresh cut green apple with a slight bit if spice. Taste is same as smell with a pleasant dry finish. Definitely more yeast in this than most ciders  used to, but is nice. Incredibly refreshing, this would be perfect on a picnic with some cheese. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. 2010 vintage. Golden - orange colour with some bubbles. Aroma is cellar, sourness, apple, wood. Flavour is cellar, sourness, smoked, apple, wood. Very nice cider.

Poured draught at Gingerman NYC.  Pours slightly cloudy without much head, medium carbonation. Aroma of tart apple and straw. Smells like an orchard!  Tast is beautiful, full bodied, balanced: tart apple with the slightest bit of honey.  Really a fantastic cider.

Cask at Churchkey. Poured a slightly cloudy, light golden color with an almost gray-green hue to it, very cider like (go figure). Aroma was really apples with some serious funk notes to it. Flavor was some woody funk, mellowed apples. Interesting to say the least.
On cask at Churchkey.  Nose is musty and dry. A bit phenolic. Flavor has apple skin and is a bit musty. Some phenols. Dry and fairly tart. Light.

Special cask tapping. Lightly carbonated, probably less so than when in bottles. Aroma of apple and straw. Definite barnyard character as others have noted, and quite tart but not sour. There is a lot of complexity in the acids of this cider and it changed as the glass warmed. Very enjoyable.

Pours a very fizzy light golden body with a huge fizzy head thats unusually long-lived for a cider. Due to the extraordinary high carbonation the it takes quite some time before the white head disappears. The aroma is strong, complex and, to a cider novice like myself, quite demanding. Sure, there are notes of fermented apples, but even stronger are pungent notes of barnyard, leather and horse. I sort of like horses, but this is almost too much. Also some very vague sulphuric notes in the back. The taste is light sweet with a moderate dry finish. The flavours follow the aroma: a sweaty horse in front, followed by a barnyard with fermented apples and leather. A bit fuller body than most ciders Ive had. A nice one, but I get this "Im not worthy" feeling while drinking it, Im sure this one is better than my simple palate manages to appreciate. 
[37.5 cl bottle, 2010 vintage, shared with my cider loving wife, from Vinmonopolet Vika, Oslo]

0.375l corked bottle. POOF! Thats a proper cork pop indeed! Almost made it to the roof. Its fizzing like Ive never seen before this. Almost like pouring soda on top of soda-pop-tablets Pale blurry and golden in the looks, and its packed with small floaters. The fizzing white top quickly fades. The nose is really oozing of cellared cork-wood. Dry floury yellow apples and some farm-like notes. Smells quite nice. Yeah, its really aggressive on the carbonation and the mouthfeel is light and almost watery. More dry and flour-like green apples with cellar, cork and wood, salty butter, some earth and dust. Quite dry in the mouth, and it has an dry apply tartness in the finish. Actually quite a nice cider this. 28.12.2012
Big blue cheese nose that is overwhelming. Moldy, funky, and rotten smells as Id expect. Tasted really nice for a normandy style cider but I bet i drank it too fresh.

Green bottle, 375 ml, from Luc Bourbonnière, drunk with Louise and Luc, savoured August 25 2012; eye: straw, hazy, average effervescence; nose: Brettanomyces yeast, slight apple, slight medicinal; mouth: aerial, light sour apple, sweet apple, Epsom salt, finale in lightly sour apple, refreshing, light body, quite carbonated, lightly sweet, light texture; overall: fine
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Bouteille verte, 375 ml, de Luc Bourbonnière, bue avec Louise et Luc, savourée le 25 août 2012; il : paille, voilée, effervescence moyenne; nez : levure Brettanomyces, très léger pomme, très léger médicinal; bouche : aérien, pomme légèrement aigre, pomme sucrée, sel dEpsom, finale en pomme légèrement aigre, rafraîchissant, corps léger, très carbonatée, légèrement sucrée, texture légère; en résumé : très bon

Bottle split with Erica at Spuyten Duyvil on 11/24/2012. Color is a medium to dark gold, solid and glassy with no head. Darker color than expected for a cider which was cool. Never had a cider like this before - extremely yeasty and higher carbonation than I have had within the style. Almost effervescent. Aroma and flavor are yeasty, barnyardy, and light citrus. Really great sipper.

Bottle, 375ml. Vintage 2010. Its an almost clear one, golden in color and with some bubbles on top. The aroma is both cellar-ish and apple-ish, with apple cores and orchard. Its full-bodied, tart and quite effervescent, having your cheeks clinging to your teeth. Its very tasteful, with cellar, orchard and lots of apples and apple cores, really balanced and pleasant. Lasting finish. A superb cider Ill certainly hunt down again. 121110
Bottle 2010, 5.5% @ FOneFan. Hazy yellow with big fully diminishing white head. Aroma is apples, barnyard and tart. Flavour is apples, high carbonation, tart, barnyard, leather and very dry.

Bottle 375ml @ fonefan
Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of sour apples, yeast and sugar. Taste is light sweet and light sour with a dry fruity finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is fizzy
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, apples, barnyard and wood. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 101112

Bottle with Ann. Pours a fizzy pale gold with lots of short lived head. Aroma has a lot of horsey brett character. Taste is a great balance of sweet apple flavors and a funky brett influence. Very carbonated, couldnt drink more than one. Really good.

Pours a clear orange with a huge white head that clears up as fast as it appears.  Sweet noes with some funk.  Borderline between nectar and brut, finishes clean, not horribly acidic considering its a cider.

Bottle. Musty horseblanket, very brett-like,  and light fruity aroma. Clear effervescent golden. Brett-like horseblanket, sweet apple, tart, light spice flavor. Light fizzy body, dry finish. My first French cider, and Im duly impressed. Not disappointed that I chose this for my 1000th rating.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2012 2011.  Golden orange body.  Large fizzy head disappears as quickly as it forms.  No lacing or residue.  Nose is lightly funky, with bright apples and must.  Flavor is juicy semi-sweet apples with some light must.  Medium to light bodied.  Assertive carbonation.  Semi-sweet finish.  A wonderful cider.

Bottle - Huge pop of the cork on this one, right as I loosened the cage. Pours light clear amber with a thin bubbly white head. Nose is plastic and leather funk, dry apple, and real light baking spice. Taste is a bit sweeter, with the plastic/leather character that recedes through the finish, letting a semi-sweet apple peek through. Smooth, light and effervescent, with big-time carbonation.

2008 vintage: A blonde cider with a thin collapsing white head. In aroma, a beautiful gueuze-like horseblanket, epsom salts, dirt cave, Brett notes. In mouth, a smooth sweet apple with skins, Brett, salts, funk, complex, sweet and refreshing. Tasted with GRM on August 28, 2012.

What a great cider.  Pours with a fizzy, medium-sized white head.  Aroma of apples fresh off the tree and a lightly tart barnyard funk.  Moderately sweet natural apple flavor perfectly paired with a nice acidic tartness.  Smooth, tasty and refreshing. Dry and slightly tart finish.

On bottle from Vinmonpolet Stovner.
Golden color, some immediate foam- then flattens out.
Good fruit/ apple intensity .
Good carbonation, soft bubbles.
Long aftertaste
Well balanced and enjoyable
Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with flakes and stems floating with paperthin head. The aroma is apple and funk. Medium mouthfeel with a funkytart and bandaids. A decent cider from Domaine.

2008 bottle shared by Dallas 
Appearance: Clear yellow with a small white head 
Aroma: Tart and  apple peel <br
Taste: Tart apples, sugar and pear 
Nice and smooth, fruity.
750 ml bottle. Soft apple, sweet apple juice, pear, fruity, apple skin. A nice apple flavor with red apple skin. Nice refreshing beverage.

Been wanting to try this forever and finally am. Pours super fizzy bright light gold. Nose of earthy apples, including seeds and dirty skins. A bit funky. Some pleasant Band-Aid. Taste adds sweetness and a light tart kick. Lively palate. Dry. Lovely.

Bottle from Red, Wine, and Brew somewhere up near Eastlake, OH.  I think I also tried one of these at a tasting courtesy of Darren, but not sure if it was the same one or not.   This is the best cider Ive had to date.  Pours with a lively champagne-like carbonation that instantly creates a large white head.  Aroma is dry with notes of sour apple and yeast.  Flavor is a nice combination of sour and sweet apples.  Finishes dry.  Super easy to drink.

2010 bottle.  hazy orange gold pour with bubbly but quickly disappearing head.  When a bit chilled - sweaty leather, wet wood, egg, apple.  When warmer - apple, caramel, brown sugar.
Much nicer when warmer.  A nice picnic drink on a warm day.
Bottled. SOur vineous nose, cloudy pour, tart and earthy. Pretty good stuff.

2010 750 c&c from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours slightly hazy orange gold with a fizzy, transient white head. Aroma of earthy, ripe - slightly overripe? - apples. Med minus body. Light carb. Flavor is earthy, astringent apple - suggests red apples. This is really drinkable. Much like a local farm cider. Ive had one better, but just one.

Sample at Monks,1999 bottle, pour resembled ginger ale, tons of sediment, no head or lacing. Aromas of pure red delicious being cut, cinnamon, granny smith skin. Taste was a little on the watery side and boring compared to the aroma when cold but as it warmed more flavor came out. Boozey apples, wood, and other spices were present.

1999 Bottle at Monks. Golden greenish yellow. No head. The sweet and sour from the apple blending well together. Mellowed quite a bit. Much of the expected funkiness has been pushed to the background. Delicate honey sweetness works with the sour but still allows a nice acidic bite. Note: Just tried a second 1999 bottle. Much more green apple taste. Less sweet. More murky in the pour. Note 2: Just had a third bottle of the 1999. All bets are off. This one tastes different than the other two. Some definite caramel notes. Obviously expect variations in taste with these older bottles!

great looking beverage with sediment in it..which I enjoy. golden colour. apple put in fresh oak barrel. Smells like a wine cellar. nice aroma. rich flavour, somewhat sweet and baked apple taste. very interesting brew!!

375ml cork n cage bottle. Golden pour with lots of little floaters. No head. Heavy funk on the nose with big cooking apple aromas behind and a fair bit of wood. Not nearly as interesting on the palate but theres lots of apple pie with an oaky edge.

The cider pours a golden color with a huge rocky white head that fizzes out in a similar fashion as a sparkling wine. There are a lot of effervescent bubbles all through out the glass of cider and the yeasty haze is very light. 

The aroma is particularly appealing seems pretty funky in a sort of hay and farm-animal kind of way at first, but that doesnt dominate the bouquet. The apple rind is more prevalent here than the fleshy part of the apple but there is plenty of that character in there as well. The Cider has fruity and mineral-y characteristics akin to a nice dry white Italian wine and is not particularly sweet smelling but perfectly balanced in every way. 

The flavor is semi-sweet and very red apple-forward right up front but this soon changes to nice light mineral and apple rind notes. The cider is nicely tart but not particularly sour, becomes very dry mid palate, and stays that way for the finish. Some light floral notes balance this out just right. 

I quite enjoy a glass (or whole bottle) of cider like this.

Aroma is apple skin and a slight mustiness.  The flavor is apples, fruit (cherry or raspberry) and is dry in finish.  Quite funky in flavor, very unique among the ciders Ive had due to the fruitiness that gives it a hard to define quality but very good even if its hard to describe.

2010 Very carbonated clear golden pour lots of receding frothy white head that leaves a ring ..... aroma is of barnyard, soured and fresh apples ... earthy and funky .... taste is crisp, earthy and of fresh apples, little funk and a little dry and sweetness that lingers into the finish ... mouthfeel is well balanced, smooth and a little lively .... awesome stuff has really aged well
Bottle 2009. Cloudy golden colour with a white foam. Dry, fruity, apples, earth, yeast, actually rather smoky and a bit funky as well. Nice!

Dry, beautifully apply and with the smell of the rind from a ripe Pont-lÉvêque.  Honey yellow, very fizzy and sweet tang though it definitely dries out with a woody finish.  The apple flavour is rustic and fresh in a chalky kinda way.

With a pale yellow body and full of bubbles, looks like a champagne. The scent is sour and spicy, like fermented apples and decomposing leaves. Tastes dry and fruity, some green apples, lemongrass and dried oranges create a sweet smooth flavor. Sour and tangy undertones bring a nice dryness that cleanses the palate.

Bottle. 2009 vintage. Cork comes out with very little effort and a start to see the bubble rise up towards the neck, quick! glass before this thing overflows everywhere. I get wafts of farmhouse and bret as I pour this out. Wonderfully carbonated and full of vigor and spirit. The nose is a nice mix of old farm, funk, and green tart apple. Light mouthfeel. Cobweb, slighlty woody, sweet apple, and caramel. Surprised at how caramel tasting this is. Ends with a lingering funkiness. Overall, pretty impressed.

From 2007 750mL bottle. Beautiful funky Normandy cider aroma, big apple and sweet musk notes. Takes me back to living in Reims. Medium amber hazy with thin white head. Medium watery body with medium to light carbonation. Starts much sweeter than I would have expected for a Brut. Great juicy apple flavors with just a hint of funk to it. A very nice cider and one I wish I could find more easily on this side of the state. Good stuff.

Had a bottle from Redlight Redlight. The vintage was 2008. Light and cloudy appearance, with very fine bubbles. The mouth feel was equatable to that of a champagne with the very light and refreshing bubbles. Amazing taste. One of my favorite ciders. Cant wait to crack open my 2010 bottle.

Tasted on 11/28/11 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle, 2010 vintage.  Pours a clear, dark yellow with a thin, fizzy white head that quickly disappears, leaving nothing behind.  There is a bit of sediment floating in my glass as well.  The nose is a combination of sweet red and tart green apples with a strong aroma of floral apple blossom, perfumed lavender, and an earthy yeast note as well.  The flavor is lightly sweet red apple up front, moving to the floral, tart green apple, and earthy yeast.  The body is light with sparkling, champagne-like carbonation, and a long, tart, dry green apple skin, and tannic finish.
sweet, dry, champagne-like carbonation with a bit of rubber/earthy funk in the nose and taste.

Bottle @ home. 2008 vintage. Cloudy, golden appearance with a carbonated head. Fairly sweet red apple, effervescent aroma. Quite carbonated, slightly funky, red apple pulpy, fairly sweet flavor with a light dryness.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012 hazy straw color with a thin but persistent white head and lots of effervescence; creamy medium-full body with soft but high carbonation.

aroma: sometimes has strong sulfur, some brett, with subtle hints of apples and sweet vanilla.

taste: nondescript sweetness, brett funkiness but not sharpness, woody vanilla, and only faint hints of apple.

it has a very strong foul smell at first, almost gag inducing, but once i got used to it, some pleasant notes emerged. the flavor is very nice. i wish i could drink it without smelling it. i actually poured the second glass and let it sit for 10 minutes before i approached it -much better.

750 mL bottle, 2009. Opens with a strong pop. Pours a straw gold with fizzy white head. The aroma is heirloom apples, a deep musty note, an interesting herbal mint tone, something I can only describe as organic acids, and even a distant hint of scorched bacon grease (!?). The flavor is nice crisp wild apple with a slight acidity and mild moldy cellar. The finish is lovely and dry with an interesting mossy and yeasty character, along with an occasional smoky hint. This here is some fine cider.

Bottle, 2009 ed. Pour is bright yellow, decent head which quick dissipates and a few floaties. Aroma is apple juice, earth, spicy/funky yeast. Taste is quite acidic, apple skins, apple juice, yeasty funk. Pretty easy drinking cider but Id rather have a beer.
tap at birch and barley.   dry herbal applce.  spices.  cinnamon.   light lemon zest.   peppery.  nice.

375ml Bottle (2009 Vintage):  Aroma of apple, oak, wood, rubber, and acid.  Poured yellow/apple juice in color with a small, very loose, off-white head that disappeared very quickly.  Hazy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of apples, wood, funk, light barnyard, and light acid.  Light body.  Tingly texture.  Lively carbonation.  Heavily sweet, apple, funk, slight wood, and light barnyard finish.

(375ml bottle. 200z vintage).  Cork blew off before I even got the cage off and I lost a bit of cidre.  Pours deep yellow with white head a and active-really active-carbonation.  Aroma of apple, spice and a bit of funk, but not belgian funk.  Taste is sweet with some spice.  A bit tart and rich.  Medium bodied with dry finish.  Really nice.  I need to explore cidres more.

Pale yellow; slightly cloudy. Very little aroma...tart, apples, dirty socks. Flavor is watery...mostly tart apples. Sour like a Flemish ale. Somewhat thin but clean finish. Ok, but Ive had better ciders.

Bottle. French ciders are quite different and less austere than English is what Ive learned. Pours a very rambunctious head, very champagne like with dissipating mousse. Pale yellow. Nose is interesting. Some ethanol comes through, as does a crisp fall apple note and cream. On taste, quite acidic, but softer. Not overbearing malic acid. Very appley, lightly sweet and clean. Does have a bit of that "cidery" ester quality that distracts somewhat, but very tasty stuff.

Tasted this a couple of times at Milltown. Bright hazy gold pour with a thin crackling head. Earthy nose with some acidity and mild funk, apple skins. Tart and crisp palate with a tart acidic apple character in the flavor with a mild wild character. Tasty enough

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2014 2009 bottling sampled June 2011.
Attractive golden pour with a nice white head. Nose of apple, must, and saison yeast, flavor follows, not particularly tart or dry but very enjoyable with the rustic yeast-forward textures. Not sure I prefer this to a farmhouse beer at the same price point, but very nice nonetheless. 7/5/8/4/15

2012 bottle from Total Wine, sampled November 2014
Visual description as above. This time apple and musty basement, also a strong sulfuric musk that is just too much. Flavor has some sweetness, but not that much, drying out late. 
I dont know whether it was there the first time and I was too intimidated by the style to complain, or whether this bottle is somehow different, but after drinking a reasonable number of additional ciders (albeit few from Normandy) Im able to say with some confidence that this isnt a characteristic that appeals to me. Mouthfeel is abundantly carbonated but soft rather than prickly. Nice. Its certainly interesting and rustic and distinct from the Washington ciders Ive had (Finnriver goes the furtherest in the complexity direction, but without the sulfur). But the almost putrid aspect detracts from my enjoyment of what otherwise would be a really nice cider. Id go about 5/4/7/4/14=3.4. Ill split the difference. 

Addendum: Holly knocks it out of the park with an aroma descriptor: "It smells like a cross between a pickle and a perm." I dunno about the pickle, but shes got it spot on with the perm. This smells like a nasty-ass hair salon.

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - cage corked 375 ml bottle. Dark golden pour, little to no head. Fresh apple aroma, golden delicious if I had to peg it, nice and natural. Flavor is smooth and crisp, apples of course, more of a mellow apple flavor, not sour like a Granny Smith, more akin to a Gala variety. Crisp mouthfeel, just the right amount of spritz. Nice change of pace.

Bottle, 2008 vintage, shared @ the Purple Pig. Hazy medium yellow gold, finely bubbled brisk carbonation. Aroma is quite geuzy, sour and musty, with petroleum vapours. Flavours are predominantly musty and woody, sour apple must, barnyard, and just a hint of burnt grass smokiness. Very dry short finish. Low sweetness. Outstanding!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: bottle - 2008 vintage - pours golden lemon with a a noticeable white head and tiny bubbles. Aroma a bit funky, barnyard and apples. Taste is aggressively sour apples on the first sip softening into barnyard on the finish. Palate is lightly creamy with average carbonation. Overall its definitely complex, but Im having trouble getting past the barnyardy-ness. More a cider you would drink to appreciate, then from its deliciousness factor.

I took the metal guard off the top, and the cork popped out on its own - now thats impresive carbonation. Pours a slightly hazy gold with no head - not particularly attractive to be honest. Aroma is nice - sour apples, celery, white wine. Taste is apples, white wine, maybe a touch of citrus too. Dry finish of sour apples. Palate is extremely bubbly - it expands inside the mouth, more than Id like in fact. It also leaves me belching every five minuets. Id like this better with less carbonation. Still, this is very good. Drinkable and enjoyable.
2006 bottle. juicy nose of red delicious skin and honeycrisp nectar. powerful effervescence in the glass, hazy gold. barnyard yeast forward, sweetens into the finish, gentle mouthfeel
2009 bottle. green apples, funk, high carb/fizzy, too sweet. some medicinal off-flavors. challenging.

Bottle, 2004 Vintage.Pours a viscous cheddar yellow with an aroma of barn attic-aged apples, musty horse blanket, and dusty air.  Flavor is barn-stored apples crushed in a dusty horse blanket, old leather, and citrus-infused vinegar.  Oily yet light on the tongue.  Very tasty; seems to be the cloning of a good cider and a great geueze in a barrel left in a barns attic for years.  Delicious.  Wish I had bought a few more.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle in a wine glass.  The beer pours a medium yellow/amber color, with a smallish white head.  Strong notes of leather and funky barnyard notes come through in the aroma, illustrating the array of brettanomyces-based compounds.  The palate shows a strong farmhouse/barnyard character up front and through the middle, before transitioning to a more traditional apple/cider character.  The finish is an interesting combination of the two, with the final note tending more toward leather than malic character.  Carbonation is assertive without being over-the-top.  Overall, the brett character adds tremendous complexity, but borders on being almost unpleasant at times.  True to the assertion of being a farmhouse cider.

shared a 750 ml bottle with some family. Nice smoke on the opening. Poured into a wine glass. Deep butter and gold color with quickly subsiding bubbles. Steadu riseing carbination. Aroma is a yeasty funk and paper mill. Taste starts a little sweet but moves to dry right away. No real apple taste but you get a little apple hint on the burp. that cargination fills the mouth and nose very well for the high palate score.

2008 vintage. Clear light brown pour with a large, effervescent yet quickly receding head. Aroma is funk, barnyard, apples. Flavor is lightly funky, dry, apples. Dry and fizzy mouthfeel. A very pleasant cider.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2012 750ml bottle of the 2010, very bad bottle, smell of cheese and garbage. Stay away. 
375ml bottle of the 2008, stated 5% abv. Opens with a huge pop. Clear golden yellow with a huge, fizzy, pure white head that quickly fades to nothing. Aroma of apple juice, oak and some light musty barnyard. Flavor is apples and some woodsy hints, kind of a sourness in the finish. Light body with explosive carbonation and a dry, light mouth feel. I like this a lot, its got a lot more going on than just apple flavors.

Funky nose with notes of apple, pear, fermentation, leather, yeast, and animal hide. Palate is not totally dry. It does have a bit of sweetness to it. Just a touch though. Simple but clean flavors without all of the funk that cam on the nose. Really thought that this was a great cider.

2007 vintage. Pours pale golden yellow color with fizzy white head. Dank aroma of green apples. Flavor is sweet, tart and musty apples. Light to medium body with effervescent carbonation. Crisp and refreshing. One of the best ciders I have tried.
750 ml bottle @ Pikkulintu. Warm, rests directly from the bottle. Tasted and smelled like a mixture of dishwasher detergent and apple. Blaah.

2005. 750mL Bottle. Distinct, flowery pollen-like yeasty Lambic must in the nose, tangy and acerbic. Pours a clouded straw golden with minimal head, but plenty of prickly carbonation. Interestingly, the lambic yeastiness fades completely from the favor profile, leaving a dry chalky fruit flesh behind thats delicate, mineral-laden, and expressive. Carbonic acids bring sweeping MacIntosh-like apple flavors, cooked apple bread, and sweet estery alcohols. The palate on this is just amazing. Dry, crisp, but full and balanced. No signs of oxidation (I think this has been in a refrigerator for most of its life). Sparkling, flavorful, and complex.

2008 750 ml bottle at DC local tasting, courtesy of tarheels86 - merci bien, mon petit frère.  Straw yellow, edge bubbles.  Aroma of warm apple puree.  Taste is smooth fruit, slightly sweaty, medium sweetness.  Tasty.

750mL. Andy and I obviously have similar tastes. It poured a cloudy light yellow with a fizzy white head that disappears quickly. Aroma right out front I thought: geuze! And then the lemony tartness, horsey notes started to give way to apple skins, leather, sour green apples. Taste is sour green apples skins, red delicious apples. Pretty yummy and one of the better ciders that Ive tried.

750ml bottle pours a lightly hazy, bright yellow with one ring of white head.  Aroma is fruity, a little cheesy, a little horsey.  Almost has a guezey kind of nose.  Flavor is sweet, fruity, lots of apples and apple juice.  Finish is sweet and a little wet.  Id like this a touch drier.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 At first impression is almost disappointingly ragged-tasting. Simple and sweet lacking acidity. A bit dilute, and musty taste of rotting underbrush. But wait!! The musty rot is taking on a stone cellar character and the tanginess of apple flesh and apple peel now comes through a bit. Actually the acidity becomes longer and more serious in gradual increments, it is actually a touch acetic. What a wild tasting cider! It is a real sipper and captures the French fascination with nobly rotting apples as an art form. In the end very good and demanding a cider.  ** LATER ADDITIONAL NOTE **  I had actually sampled this a year earlier, at Ginger Man.- described it as having a Duchesse-like Lambic quality, less sweet, nice oldness (I love that!) and beautiful lacing (?) It was less challenging that time, was the Cidre a little different in May 2009 or was it me? Obviously a beer to adventure with every time you see it.

First thoughts: Cork is pulled from small magnum...a few large bubbles flow from liquid...all is still untill first gentle pour into tall glass.  A steady rolling boil-like carbonation begins and steadily keeps a 1/8th bright white head. Medium to deep golden....Ift this is actually unfiolteredas the label states, then I got a mid siphon bottle well away from any sediment.  Nose of tart apples rolled in honey.  Nose translates smoothly to taste but with a lighter finish.  Overall the cider is sweet and mostly monotoned.  Some hints of apple body emerge briefly but then are overtaken and muted to a light tar.  Nice on a hot day.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a light clear gold.  Loads of fresh tart apples on the nose.  Maybe just a hint of cinnamon or other spices.  The flavor is as close to a granny smith apple as I can imagine cider getting: sweet, tart, and delicious.  Drier than some ciders but still refreshing enough to wet a thirsty throat.  This is definitely one of the best ciders on the market.

Draft @ Coles, Buffalo NY. pours a bright gold with quickly disapating white head. Full aromas of apple, sweet sugar & band aid. Taste is sweet apples, band aid , dry. Ciders are really not my thing but this is damn good

2008 375mL bottle from VBM in Buffalo. I dont know why but Ive been craving a good cider lately and this hit the spot! Pours a pale golden yellow body with some tiny apple? pieces floating around. Short lived big, white head. Mild musky, light apple, pear and basement aroma. Flavor is the perfect amount of sweet apples and that typical dry brut characteristic. Fizzy mouthfeel to start which mellowed out very nicely. Thin bodied. Great cider, the best I think Ive ever tried.

Bottle. Pours golden and fizzy. The aroma is way funky, almost bretty but not quite. Similar flavor, tart apples with an almost bretty like funkyness and a dry finish. Way different than any cider ive ever had, but quite good.

golden amber with large white head.  nose of oak and sweetness.  high carbonation.  flavor with some oak before some funky esters, from wild yeast, then some sweetness.  not a dry cider by any means, but very complex and flavorful.  wonderful

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2013 375 served with some crazy good cod fritters. Served into a Saison Dupont glass.


Clear, saturated golden hue. White ring of fizz. A couple nucleation points in the glass that easily amuse me.


Smell is of baked apples, hay, sulfur, & a light green apple tartness. Bright & somewhat floral. A less muddled bottle then the one I picked up from New Beer Distributors sweat shop factory.


Taste is bittersweet upfront, slightly briny, with a rounded, zesty, & juicy center. Some drying wood tannins. Incredibly refreshing. Minor solvent finish.

Light chalkiness, moderate acidity, & overactive to a slightly harsher point then champagne. A little heft to the body keeping the finish from being anything more then slightly dry.

Love it. :)
user_location: FT: Stale Polotmavý in Queens, New York, USA

text:
Bottle corked and caged from Keg Liquor.

Poured clear yellow color with a minimal white head that diminished quickly with minimal lacing. Moderate to heavy aroma  of green apple. Light to medium body with a dry texture and lively carbonation. Light sweet & sour apple flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration.

My expectations were met.

Bottled. Cork made a nice flight already when removing the metalpart, yet no fountain came out of the bottle. Bigtime earthy and barnyardy notes along with some sour apples as well as mild vanilla and herbal notes. Flavour is quite earthy and dusty along with some apples as well as some wooden notes. Biting carbonation. Rather dry, but yet very refreshing cider.

2007 bottle. Bottle exploded as I opend this one..wow real barnyard/horseblanket nose. I cant pick up any apple in the nose. Pale blond frothy loose head.  Dry, little sweet..odd flavor on the finish....plastic....this is interesting?

Unclematties girlfriend shared this with us.  Yellow pour.  Smells of delcicious apples, tart and sweet.  Flavor is purely delicious.  Concentrated sweet/tart apples.  Crisp and wonderfully carbonated like champagne.  NICE!!

Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow with a vigorous and large white foam head that holds for a moment and then falls off, finally allowing me to pour in a full glass.  Slight farm/hay notes  but nothing jarring or offensive, champage yeast.  Smells a bit like a very light sour beer, so a big plus for me. Sweet, but nothing cloying, just a very soft straight forward ripe apple sweetness.  Finishes gently and quietly, fading off into light apple and a touch of apple skin.  Delicious.

Served up in a Champagne flute at Leons Full Service in Decatur, Georgia.

Appearance: Lightly hazed, pale yellow body with a very thin, very fizzy layer of white bubbles. Constant effervescence.

Smell: Aromatic assortment of sweetish apple-based notes: apple cores, apple peelings, sliced apple wedges, apple juice. Theres also some background funkiness present.

Taste: Apples, baby! Providing some tartness, some fruitiness, some juicy sweetness, but theres also some barnyard funkiness to it. So, its not just a farm-fresh apple, but a farm-fresh apple served up right on the farm. Finishes fairly dry.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium-plus carbonation.

Drinkability: Enjoyable! After so many cheap, inferior mass-produced ciders, this is a pleasant change of pace.

Bottle. Pours light golden coloured with a nice bubbly white head. Aromas of apples, hay, honey and musty basement. Lovely fruity apple flavour with notes of funk, sweet honey and sour fruit. Great but a little expensive cider..

Yellow bubbly our with foamy white head and lace. Aroma is apples, paper, and straw. Medium apple flavor with sweet/sour tones at the same time. A foamy medium bodied drink. A bit of cloying sweetness in the finish that I found to be a bit appealing.

Best cider ever, thats relative, but this was exceptional.  The aroma was full of that farmhouse/ deep lambic-saison aromas.  Very tart aromas.  The appearance was a clear gold pour, with a bubbly white head.  The flavor full of farmhouse-tart apple, green apple, and interestingly some pear or peach overtones.  The feel is effervescent with a nice clean feel.

Sampled at Beerhawks Beer Gods in the Boro, aka 1000 Bottles of Beer on the Wall, By God Beer God Gathering, BG1K Tasting.  2007 bottle. Clear gold pour.  Peachy.  Crazy tart flavor and almost like a lambic.  Refreshing and dry finish, though I really didnt care for this personally.

2007 Bottle. Poured golden with a fizzy white head. Tart aroma of barnyard and hints of green apple. The flavor has a little more apple standing out and is more sweet than tart. Light body yet "fuller" than any other cider Ive had to this point. Dry texture. Very decent cider.

BeerHawks Beer Gods in the Boro, aka 1000 Bottles of Beer on the Wall, By God Beer God Gathering, BG1K Tasting. Sample from a bottle thanks to BeerHawk.  2007 vintage.  Clear golden yellow with a thin fuzzy white head.  Sugar aroma, candy, a bit of barnyard funk.  Taste is sweet sugar, rock candy, not much apple fruit.  Seems a bit plastic-y.

On tap at Ginger Man, NYC. Quenched the "hard cider" craving, but was not remotely quenching in character thanks to that uber-dry finish. Enjoyable if you want a nice hard and dry cider. Drink very cold. Disagree with other comments on sweetness- yes, its apple flavoured, but it definitely was not sweet compared to most other ciders (Harpoon, Woodchuck, etc).

On tap at Ginger Man, NYC. A good, balanced, tasty, easy-drinking cider right up until the finish, which is probably the driest of any cider Ive ever had. I understand its "brut, but it would be hard to get through a pint of it without needing IV fluids.

(11/17/08) Bottle at Birreria Paradiso in Washington DC. 5.0%. Hazy golden color with a big white head that falls immediately. Aroma of sour green apples and some barnyard. Sourish flavor, a bit funky, of green apples and a bit of sweet tones. Mouthfeel might be the most carbonated Ive ever had. Very tasty stuff.

2007 corked 375 into snifter, served at cellar temp %0F.  My first REAL cider... here we go.  I have feared this for a long time and never seen it happen -- upon opening the cage slowly, the bottles pressure forced the cork out once the cages counter pressure was released upon me untwisting it!  Thankfully, I untwisted the cage slowly due to my fear of this reaction!  Thankfully, again, I didnt loose any liquid.  Once the cork popped, tons of bubbles started racing from the bottom of the bottle to the top -- big fat bubbles.  Big fizzy very rapidly fading head exactly like that resulting from a hard pour of a sprite.  Pale gold body with more raising carbonation than a Macro pale lager!!  So much so that it is actually building the head back up. Very earthy aroma with hints of sour apple, a gueuze-is tartness/crispness, oak, and a humid mustyness  -- all very subtle on the whole.  The flavor is pretty unique and also very subtle in character.  Sweet apples upfront that fades into a crist slightly tart dryness that finishes juicy with a flavor that I can only liken the the aroma of Band-Aids, if that makes any sense.  Very light body with more carbonation than I have ever encountered (again, like in a sprite).  Overall: not quite my thing, but interesting at the very least.  Not worth the price IMO, but worth a try at least once.  Inoffensive.  The Band-Aid flavor has vanished after the first few sips.  It just seems like a very subdued beverage.  Refreshing in the summer.  No trace of alcohol.  Almost tastes like it is good for me - like carbonated organic apple juice.

pours nice golden with mild carbonation, smells of (we though, paste alkaselzer or sulfur), very delicate apple/yeast combo on mouth and lingering of yeast.  Good taste, terrible smell (someone probably really appreciates this smell).
dry slight vinegar nose, bit of yeast character.  flavor of nearly overripe apples, but the yeast again really makes this interesting. very funky. good cider, not the run of the mill stuff

07 bottle. Pours a hazy straw color with a fizzy white head that quickly disappears. Nose is apples, plastic, barnyard, and wet dog. Taste is caramel apples and a fleshy sort of fruit after taste that is semi dry and fizzy. Rustic but good.

Pours a golden yellow with a foam white head and champagne-like carbonation.  Smells like tart apples and a garbage can.  Taste is fairly strong on the vinegar with some sweetness and tartness.  I do not know if this is a bad bottle or I just do not like it, but I do not think it is very good.

2007 vintage 750 ML from Malt & Vine. 5.5% ABV. Peaty farm aroma. Bubbles all the way through to the bottom of the glass. Light honey color. Fresh, tart taste of Granny Smith apples, lemon zest, and pecan. A somewhat sweet finish that stays in your cheeks.
Bottle. Yellow colour with some green notes. Vinous bitter apples in aroma. Dry sweet crispy apples in flavour. Body id soft. Good cider indeed.

750ml bottle, 2007 Vintage.  Pours a ridiculously effervescent straw color with a fleeting white head.  The aroma is on the bubbly and sweet side, though the taste is actually a little more crisp and tart -- the body is full and fruity with some added hints of grain and earth alongside the apples.  One of the best ciders out there with good cause.

Light and crisp aroma with just a touch of lemon zest. Overall flavor embodies the tart apple flavor that makes for a superior French cidre, but has yet to compare to some of the smaller labels available in France. Nice effervescence - it gives it a very lively quality. Would be great with Livarot!
Botella. Unclear pale golden. Nice apple tart bit rubber aroma. The flavour is sweet and tart with plenty of apples. Sweet apple finish.

ar: sour, acid, applr. 
clear yellow, small white head,
fl: citrussy acid, with los of sweetness from applers. quite okay, but lacks finesse. tasty but not fantastic.

Vintage 2007.
Pours a very active, absurdly effervescent head that falls quickly and is somewhat spongey.
Lightly hazy golden.
Dusty, sulfury, cider apple aroma.
Somewhat sweet, dusty, reminiscent of gueuze.
Cidery, strong apple character.
Slight lingering sweetness, late smoke character.

Really loved the color on this one.  A 2005 bottle.  Lively head.  Nose was of oak, Fresh apples, light caramel, some smoke.  Flavors of wood, light leather, red apples, and sundried fruit.  Medium to light palate.  Very good and complex.

750ml bottle.  2006.  The aroma was slightly musty with plenty of fruit and apple cider.  Very Champagne like with frothy bubbles on the nose.  The flavor was similar with (again) apple cider and touches of cinnamon.  A bit of sweet also but nothing over done.   A solid effort and I would get it again.
Bottle at EBF08. Weak apple aroma. Almost clear golden colour. Good citric apple flavour, nice and round. Finally a cider that is not crap.

[EBF @ Copenhagen, September 2008] Thanks to Morten. Average bubbly white head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Clear sparkling pale yellow color. Lovely complex cider with notes of fresh apple, barnyard, vinegar, citrus, dusty fruity feel. Medium to full bodied with an average carbonation and dry texture. Moderated acidic flavor with good counter sweetness. Lasting apple and dusty dry finish. Wow that was a very solid Cider!

Sampled from bottle at State Line, 2006 vintage. The pour was hazy golden in color, ample carbonation to display. The aroma was farhouse funky apples, musty cellar elements, some cinnamon too. The flavor was excellent, about as impressive as a straight cider could be. Funky musty apples with an earthy softness and woody presence. Mouthfeel was effervescent, finishes semi-dry. Thanks, Robert, good stuff, my go-to cider now (not that I ever "go-to" such things, but when I have the urge....)!

37.5 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a fully gone head. Nice phenolic and dry apple aroma. Smooth apple flavour with a nice wooden and almost smoked note. Lingering sweet yet subdued finish with smooth fruity note.

Pours clear, light yellow with a fluffy, light head. Aroma is corky and apple. Flavor is excellent. Very corky and oaky with a delicate apple flavor. Light on the tongue with a pleasant carbonation. Rather dry. Very good!
Smells kind of funky; like the cork. I like the flavor of this. It’s not crispy but it has a strong apple flavor nonetheless. Really this was pretty good.

Bottle 375ml @ home.[Vintage 2005] Light unclear light yellow orange color with a large, frothy, virtually none lancing, fully diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is apple, barnyard, citurs bitter, rubber and wood notes. Flavor is moderate sweet, light light acidic and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft to lively. (050608)

2004 Bottle. Nearly lost my eye on this bottle. I gave the cage one twist of the wires and the cork and cage assembly exploded in my hand. Violent gushing for a couple of seconds (lost about an eighth of the bottle first pour is violently carbonated, like champagne, nearly all foam, and then the bubbles appear violent in the glass. Golden yellow, chill hazed body. Second pour yeilds a white head that stays for the duration of the drink. Nose of apples, lemon citrus, horseblanket and earthiness. Taste is pretty darn dry (not Austrian Trocken, but still pretty dry). Taste is overrippened apples, earthiness, and a bit of plastic-funkiness in the finish. Sharp champagne like carbonation, and a dry mouthfeel. Gets better the more I drink it.

Ça sent et goûte le cuir et ça me rappelle donc les nanas sexys des gars de goths où je me suis déjà promené. Cest très doux et ça rappelle même un peu en fait ces célèbres mélanges de 7UP/Sprite et de jus de pommes que les potes et moi vendions aux nanas délurées de Ste-Foy, jadis. Cest jolimment jaune et le col blanc mousseux ne disparaît jamais. Fort agréable ! Mais ce dont je me souviendrai toujours, cest cette odeur de cuir... miam !

2006 bottle.  Clear gold pour with a white head that fades almost immediately.  Sweet but tart apple aroma with a faint yeastiness and some noticeable horse blanket.  Tart and astringent apple up front which fades to sweet green apple, yeast and faint sour funk.  Dry medium body with lots of tingly carbonation.

From bottle Vintage 2005 : Pours a hazy amber color with a small white fizzy head that dies out after a minute or two.  Nose is sweet, with sour apples.  First impression is that the body is thick, quite thick.  Has a sweet taste, some sour apples toward the end, and ends very dry....very dry indeed.  Some apple lingers in the aftertaste, and the dry tartness.  Not to bad, it is my first real cider, so i dont have much to compare it with though.

Vintage 2006. Warm golden with a quickly disappearing head. The aroma has a light sweetness, notes of ripe apples, light barnyard and damp basement. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of slightly sweet apples with a natural sourness, fermented apple, light, damp cellar and wood. Not bad at all!

Bottle, bought @ Vinspecialisten, Kolding Storcenter.[vintage 2005]
Pours clear golden with a green-yellow hue. When poured, there is a medium, fizzy white head, but it quickly disappears. Instead the stunning amount of fresh bubbles surching towards the top, forming a new, continually regenerating white head. Aroma is great, lots of fresh, green apples as well as a slight funkiness of overripe red apples. High and lively carbonation. Flavour is wonderfully balanced between slight woodiness, heavy fresh apples, light funk and a general good balance. Wonderful.
37,5cl bottle @ VinensVerden,Odense. Wauw - what a cider- funky fresh. Hazy yellow with a off white head. Fruity apple. fresh, tart & sweet. Dry & perfectly carbonated! Yessir!
Pours clear and golden.  Nice small white head leaves some lacing.  This cider has a heavy apple aroma.  Slightly tart with a sweet finish.  Very nice!! Very nice!!
Pours clear golden with a small cap white head.  Apples meet the nose along with a yeasty aroma.  Taste is tart meets sweet.  Apple and honey is prevalent.  Finishes dry.

bottle pours a hazzy golden apple juice colour with a lasting bubbly white head. aroma is a musty apple pulp aroma, some bright tart areas and some sweeter fresh pressed apple juice underneath, honey and some perfumy notes. the flavour is very tart and fades in to a lazy apple flavour that is not to powerful, some yeast and some sweetness finds its way in somewhere. finishes quick and dry with some must character. not overly impressed but very drinkable.

Bottle @ redlight redlight. Pours hazy golden with a fizzy white head that fades to the edges quickly. Apples in many modes, a tart green apple along with a more caramel apple undernote, a little yeasty spice and some musty notes. Tart, apples, sweet, a little drying tannic note, and finishes a little musty. Nicely carbonated.

I thought this was absolutely horrid.  I really wanted to like this but I much prefer the english dry ciders, but I wanted to give this a chance.  I just could not get past all the phenolics.  Too woody and vinous, with lots of vinegar aromas.  Way too funky for my palate.

Apple skins come off the nose right away, fresh apples with a slight mustiness. Pours cloudy golden yellow with a thick white head at first that dissappears quickly.  Very carbonated, tart apples, granny smith-like flavors, apple skins with a musty funky finish that is slightly dry.

2002: Apple aroma, slightly vinegary with some butter and clove. Opaque gold with lots of floaties. Musty with crisp apples and some chlorophenols. Slightly bready finish. Nicely tart but quite off. Once you acclimate yourself to the phenols, its not that bad.
375 ml bottle. Year: 2005. Smells nice, but the taste does not at all live up to the aroma of appels. The taste is overwhelmed by yeast - not pleasant.
750ml 2005 - Copper color, lightly fizzy, yeasty apple nose, maybe some cinnamon, mildly sweet apple on plate.  Nice.
Heavy yeasty aroma. Clear yellow body. Heavy acidic initial flavor. Medium palate.

Bottle 2002. First cider since Ive been rating, even mentally. That said, nice tart, funky aroma. The flavor had a hint of what to me is old cheese (I do remember experiencing this in a cider ages ago, maybe its just me), but largely strong with tart and sour apple, a funky-spicy finish. End of the glass yields uber-sour apple, in a good way. Enjoyable drink.

2002 vintage bottle.  Poured a light yellow/orange, hardly any head.  Aroma of sour tartness.  Taste of tart fruits (raspberry, apple), and I also got some strange flavors: barbeque sauce and medicinal esters (reminded me of laughing gas from the dentist).  Regardless of the odd flavors though, it was quite delicious and not too sour.

2002 vintage.  Lighter golden color with a big, noisy, fizzy head.  Aroma has some nice sour/sweet apple essence with a bit of funkiness.  Flavor starts with a nice sour appleyness with a good sour bite.  Goes a bit flat later on, something I did not experience with the Calvados aged version - a year or tow past its prime?  Maybe, but still a good cider.
Bottle.  Hazy yellow colour with medium frothy white fully diminishing head. Fruity aroma. Mostly apple. Sweet flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2008 Great cider, carbonated like a chanpiegne. Sharp on the tounge at first taste, interestng on your palate. Well balanced. Airy, Flavor of sour apples. This cider makes origional sin its bitch. Would live to get another bottle. Drank at LExpress in lower manhattan.

Bottle at JK ODonnells Irish Pub, Fort Wayne, IN. 5.5%ABV bottle.Small fizzy off-white head that quickly dissipated and cloudy. Aroma was apples, sweet and somewhat tart. Ditto for the flavor. Fairly smooth mouthfeel and light-medium body. A cider worthy of a try and one that I would drink again.

2004 bottle. Apple rind, oxidized apple aroma, with lots of a distinct yeast culture Ive found from all Dupont stuff. Very chewy, gritty, tasty, a stylized take on apple that really shows off some interesting characteristics. This is a great cider, and would serve as a fitting introduction for someone looking to get into them.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Huge head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are barnyard, stable, apples and sulphur. Nice and tart with a long dry finish. Yummy.

Original rating Feb 21 2008:Bottle. 2005 version. Nice head with ok duration. Color is yellow. Aroma and taste are apple and more apple. Smooth and well balanced. 7/2/7/3/14
Bottle. 2005. Nice warm yellow colour. Wonderfull powerfull apple aroma and flavor. Oily palate. Excellent cider.

This corked and caged bottled brew marked 2005 with D518 on the cork from a bottle shop poured a very large sized head of frothy medium sized clear colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing to nothing and left behind a hazy body with floating yeast chunks in a typically carbonated transparent yet hazy yellow-white colored body.The carbonation lasted a very long time.   The red apple aroma was very nice. The mouth feel was very tingly and bubbly at the start and at the finish with a bubbly aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of apple. A wonderful best in class brew.  A wonderfully nice all-around cider.

2005 vintage. Pours cloudy murky pressed apple honey golden color with lots of sediment. Aroma is complex, musty and tart. Flavors are nothing like that, and far more simple. Clean but slightly sweet and very thick slightly sticky palate. Very enjoyable and well-made.

Aroma is funky with sweet honey and apple, not to mention some cork.
Taste is sweet and gushing with honey and apple, not to mention some musty cork.
Matches very well with bleu cheese.  Very good.

2005 vintage.  Pours fairly dark orange for a cider.  Aroma is mostly apple (go figure) with maybe a bit of vanilla or cinnamon.  Body is tending towards full for a cider with mostly sweet apple flavors.  Some good acid gives good balance, decent carbonation makes it drinkable.  Very tasty.
Bottle. 06 vintage  I am not much of a cider drinker, however this one I liked.  It is a great balance of dry and sweet.  Very pleasant to drink.

2005 vintage: I would like to say firstly that my experience with ciders is extremely limited, consisting of Woodchuck, Johnny Appleseed and a couple others I cant remember. With that being said, this is the best cider I have yet to come across. Pours out visibly effervescent clear gold with a fizzy head, reducing to nothing within seconds. The nose is musty, cheesy, and tart green apples with some light acetic acid (vinegar). The flavour is not as tart as the aroma suggests and the finish is all green apples, though the finish is very short. The finish is also characterized by its dryness and a breif sweet lingering. Suggestions of cinnimon are striking me in the mid-palate profile, as well as sweet vanilla custard? I expected more barnyard funk and leather judging by the aroma, but such flavours were absent. Very enjoyable!

After pouring it into a pilsner glass it fizzed right up then faded just as quick. It has  cheese and apple on the nose with some funk. the flavor is about the same green apple finish with cheese and vanilla in the begining. Over all it is a nice any time drink.
Shared with Padrefan98.  Aromas were tart up front.  Tart apple and cherry.  Flavors were sweet apple and apple pie.  Very very good
Bottle purchased and shared at Liars Club in Alpine. Very nice crisp smells and flavors of Apple Pie, Cinnamon, and sweetness. Very tasty.

2006 It pours furiously with a big head that fades almost instantaneously. The extremely strong carbonation is represented by a crazy amounts of bubbles flying throughout the glass. The cider is a dark yellow color and its actually difficult to see through it because of the vigorous carbonation. Aroma is strong with a lightly wild, faintly tart, sweet musky apple. A hefty musk followed by a sharp, short sweetness. Taste is just a nice light apple sweetness. Leaves a faintly wild and tart, lightly sweet aftertaste. The carbonation is really not as felt as one would think looking at the cider.  But it is enough not to make the cider seem too-light.  Extremely quaffable, feel like it can be drank all day.  Bottom line, perfect light sweetness with faint wild characteristics.750mL, wine glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: On tap at Rich Os. 2005 vintage. hazy orange apple juice color. nice balanced mix of bright clean sour apple jolly rancher and horse blanket. sweet slightly tart apple flavor with a bit of horse blanket. tart medium dry apple finish with a bit of horse blanket. light to medium body. interesting subtle but lively almost fizzy carbonation...very nice. very nice.

750 corked and caged 2005 label poured a slightly hazed wheat apple color with a great initial rush of carbination. aroma of apple, slight tartness, and some musty funk. flavor is initially a little sweet then goes to a tart finish. nice and dry with crisp apple flavor, easy to drink and definitely best right after it is poured as the carbination quickly falls off. bought this to have with the t-day turkey this year and really quite liked it, good excuse to buy a nice cider like this one. really had a nice fresh apple taste to it.

750, corked and baled. Pours crystal clear medium gold with a fast-rising, fast-falling, fizzy platinum blonde head. Nice big funky horse blanket nose with must and dust and green apples mixed in. Light, slightly fizzy body. Beautiful green apple mid-palate with very faint undertones of horse blanket, perfect balance between sweet and dry, Refreshing and drinkable and not at all cloying or sharp. Clean finish.

Pours amber and cloudy with a fizzy quickly dissipating head.  Smells of apples and some underlying woodiness.  Elements of tartness and funk are also present.  Tastes of dry and tarte apples with some elements of hay and syrup.  A little overdone on the sweetness end of the spectrum, but still enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours hazy amber with lots of carbonation. Aroma is fresh green apples, with some dust and mediciney herb aromas in the background. Flavor has a rush of light sweetness upfront, and dry green apple flavors, some other misc earthy-planty flavors. Finish has more of the herbal medciney stale taste as well as some dryness and tartness. Mouthfeel is light and carbonated.

[Bottle, I believe from a Cellars Tasting] Pours cloudy golden with dark particles floating about and a good white head.  Tart apple aroma and taste with a good amount of spice.  A little thin.  Decent finish.  A decent cider, definitely didnt blow me away.
